newsitem.title: GERMANY: Commerzbank sees on-time start for EMU.
newsitem.headline: Commerzbank sees on-time start for EMU.

text.p: International financial markets now expect European monetary union (EMU) to start on time in January 1999 with Germany in the starting line-up, Commerzbank AG said in a study released on Wednesday.

The bank said its "EMU Probability Indicator" rose to 71 in the week ended April 1 from 64 the week before. France, Austria, the Benelux countries, Spain and Portugal also have the same probability of being among the starters, it said.
Italy has a 55 percent likelihood of being among the initial EMU members, but Britain has no chance, it said.

The indicator is based on a comparison of futures contracts on government bonds of prospective candidates. The terms of such futures should converge as the likelihood of any given country joining EMU increases.
Countries joining EMU will eliminate foreign-exchange risk relative to other members, so returns on their bonds should approach one another.
